properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued By The Town Of Gravelbourg
properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain possible overnight into Saturday morning. A low pressure system approaching the area will bring a mix of rain, snow and freezing rain to the area beginning overnight. Precipitation may begin as rain or freezing rain, then transition to snow Saturday afternoon. Freezing rain may persist for several hours before changing to snow. Snow will continue Saturday night with total snowfall amounts up to 10 cm possible before tapering off on Sunday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-02T11:40:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-01T19:41:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2540398046.2020
Area: Webequie, Fort Hope - Lansdowne House - Ogoki
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain today and tonight followed by heavy snow on Saturday. A low pressure system approaching from Saskatchewan will spread an area of rain through central and southern Manitoba today. As this system moves into Ontario overnight, an additional swath of rain will fall over central areas before transition to snow early Saturday morning. For the community of Norway House and surrounding area, rain will begin this morning and intensify this afternoon and evening with total rainfall amounts reaching 30 to 50 mm over the next 24 hours. As cold air moves south overnight, the rain will transition to snow and continue on Saturday. Total snowfall accumulations are still highly variable at this time but it is possible that greater than 15 cm of snow will fall in the region. Snowfall warnings may be issued at a later time. In the Island Lake region, rain will begin this afternoon and intensify in the evening bringing total rainfall amounts of 15 to 25 mm. As cold air moves south overnight, an area of freezing rain develops near the communities of Oxford House and Gods Lake and eventually into Island Lake by morning. The rain and freezing rain then transitions to snow in the morning. Total snowfall accumulations are still highly variable at this time but it is possible that greater than 15 cm of snow will fall in the region. Freezing rain and/or snowfall warnings may be issued at a later time. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-02T09:45:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-01T17:46:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3216761675.2020
Area: Molson Lake and Bear Lake, Cross Lake and Jenpeg, Wabowden, Hwy 6 between Little Limestone Lake and Ponton, Norway House, Oxford House and Gods Lake, Red Sucker Lake, Island Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Total rainfall: generally near 50 mm except 50 to 80 mm or more in the Burgeo - Ramea area. Locations: Port aux Basques, Burgeo - Ramea, and Connaigre. Time span: early Saturday morning until early Sunday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-05-02T17:08:11-00:00

Area: Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system currently over Manitoba is spreading rain through central Manitoba. Cold air will sweep into the area as this low tracks towards Ontario tonight, transitioning the rain to wet snow. The snow will continue through Saturday, leaving accumulations of 10 to 20 cm in its wake. While snow is expected throughout the Thompson region, the heavy snow will occur south of the city of Thompson. The rain will transition to snow near midnight in Norway house, and overnight in Island Lake. The snow will begin to taper off Saturday afternoon in Thompson and Saturday evening in Norway House and Island Lake. Along with the snow, there is potential for freezing rain to develop with this system, notably over the Norway House and Island Lake regions. The potential for freezing rain for these communities exists overnight and into Saturday early morning. Please refer to the public forecasts for more details. And stay alert for updated warnings. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-02T19:55:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-02T03:56:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0343421492.2020
Area: Molson Lake and Bear Lake, Cross Lake and Jenpeg, Wabowden, Hwy 6 between Little Limestone Lake and Ponton, Norway House, South Indian Lake and Amisk Prov. Park, Split Lake and York Landing, Thompson Thicket Portage and Pikwitonei, Nelson House, Oxford House and Gods Lake, Red Sucker Lake, Island Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant amounts of snow and freezing rain expected to arrive overnight. A low pressure system approaching the area will bring a mix of rain, snow and freezing rain. Precipitation is expected to begin as rain and then transition to freezing rain or snow as temperatures fall to near or slightly below the freezing mark. Freezing rain may persist for several hours before changing to snow Saturday morning. Snow will continue into Saturday night before tapering off on Sunday morning. Total snowfall amounts of 15 cm are possible. In addition, strong northeasterly winds of 40 gusting to 60 km/h, combined with snow, may result in blowing snow and reduced visibility. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-02T18:06:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-02T02:07:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3626929977.2020
Area: Sachigo Lake - Bearskin Lake, Big Trout Lake - Kasabonika, Sandy Lake - Weagamow Lake - Deer Lake, Summer Beaver - Wunnummin Lake - Kingfisher Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 20 to 35 mm Location: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair Time span: today and tonight. Remarks: The rain will mix with or change to wet snow early Sunday morning before ending Sunday afternoon. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
